snippet: After changes were made to the exams, education officials and activists were waiting on Tuesday to see how many students would sit them out.
abstract: New York State education officials and activists are eager to see how many parents choose to have their third- through eighth-grade children opt out of statewide testing in 2016; some 20 percent of students declined test in 2015, leading to number of changes including shorter test and removal of time limit on exam sessions; families participating in so-called opt-out movement have been calling for even greater number of students to refuse tests despite changes.

byline.original: By ELIZABETH A. HARRIS and KATE TAYLOR

lead_paragraph: After changes were made to the exams, education officials and activists were waiting on Tuesday to see how many students would sit them out.

headline.main: Big Question on New York State Tests: How Many Will Opt Out?
headline.print_headline: Big Question on State Tests: How Many Will Opt Out This Year?
